div.p: A Requiem for Soldiers lost in Ocean Transports[criticism][interpretation] Martin Griffin notes that the poem raises awareness of a marginalized experience. While the naval battles were memoralized in story and song, naval troop transports found no place among the favored settings of popular memoralization. (Ashes of the Mind, 76). (Max Bock / Eric Meckley)

When, after storms that woodlands rue, To valleys comes atoning dawn, The robins blithe their orchard-sports renew; And meadow-larks, no more withdrawn, Caroling fly in the languid blue; The while, from many a hid recess, Alert to partake the blessedness, The pouring mites their airy dance pursue. Save them that by the fabled shore, Down the pale stream are washed away, Far to the reef of bones are borne; And never revisits them the light, Nor sight of long-sought land and pilot more; Nor heed they now the lone bird's flight Round the lone spar where mid-sea surges pour.
